channel.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
channel.description:
Here is a function I made for Cheat Macro version 1.1, I hope you guys enjoy this. Please comment:
http://www.uppit.com/AL14O

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

I have a question.
What exactly is sent?
I mean… does it just send cursor coordinates? Or does it also send timestamps and such? So even if it was fluid motion, if it occurred lightning fast, they would know.

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

They send all of the mouse movements to the server, where presumably they apply some type of algorithm to decide if a human or computer moved the mouse in that path.

We KNOW the mouse movements get sent to the server, we DON’T KNOW what is done with them when they get there.

Any more questions about it? I’ll try to answer

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

You could just set a mouse hook on the applet window and block all mouse messages in the callback function.
But that’s not the main problem.

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @Portal Portal
item.description:
@Portal wrote:

@Mopman: yea I really wouldn’t know since I havent used VB in some time now. I just figured it would be ideal for it to be done in Java when working with an applet.

Remember there are other things you can use Silent Mouse for other than RS, I mean if you got good with it im sure there are other implementations it can be useful for :).

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Portal, post:23, topic:52610”]Not only that but with VB you wont be able to lock the rs client from you using your mouse too, so it may interveen. I believe it would be ideal for it to be in java and each applet instance to have focus when appropriate, its own fake mouse that leaves out whatever your real mouse does.

Anyways to stay back on track cool work with your vb, keep havin fun[/quote]

I don’t see why you couldn’t “block” the real mouse in VB, if you can do it in Java.

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @Portal Portal
item.description:
@Portal wrote:

Not only that but with VB you wont be able to lock the rs client from you using your mouse too, so it may interveen. I believe it would be ideal for it to be in java and each applet instance to have focus when appropriate, its own fake mouse that leaves out whatever your real mouse does.

Anyways to stay back on track cool work with your vb, keep havin fun

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

No.

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @terrankiller terrankiller
item.description:
@terrankiller wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:52610”][quote author=cruel link=topic=74039.msg832842#msg832842 date=1169979969]
They know when you’re sending clicks to the applet when it’s not focused (which is normally not possible). That’s how it’s detectable.
I doubt they track mouse movements in any complex manner. Human mouse movements, splines, and such seem like overkill to me… but w/e. Better to be safe than sorry.
[/quote]

Depends what you call complex. They definately do more than just check if you’re clicking without focus.[/quote]

Yes, there probably is more than that, but Clicking without focus is the main dead give away.

Read full topic

item.title: [Source][VB6] Silent Mouse
item.dc:creator: @anti-mac anti-mac
item.description:
@anti-mac wrote:

just make the window really small and have it with always on top checked and change the event for losing focus to give it focus

you probably cant do anything while thats happening but you could have like 3 autoprograms fighting for focus
